ygData.subject: Re: Zone times [OT]
ygData.msgSnippet: This is probably going to start another nasty thread, but the zoning times in EQ are enforced long time periods.  This is to make zoning intentially tedious so
ygData.messageBody:
This is probably going to start another nasty thread, but the zoning times in
EQ are enforced long time periods. This is to make zoning intentially tedious
so that you don't overuse zoning to escape from monsters. I played on an
analog 56k modem connecting at 48000 downstream and 28000 upstream, and when I
got 128K upstream, 128K downstream ISDN there was almost no difference in
zoning times.

Crier Sharpsong - 25th on Fennin Ro

Jason A. Farqu´┐¢
CDI at http://www.pigging.com/



----- Original Message -----
From: Daniel P. Sniderman <fuzzbone@...>
To: <eqbards@onelist.com>
Sent: Friday, October 01, 1999 5:21 PM
Subject: [eqbards] Zone times [OT]


> From: "Daniel P. Sniderman" <fuzzbone@...>
>
> It's ENTIRELY CPU related. I recently upgraded my X2 connection which
> averaged about 41-48K (of course that's upstream only 31K downstream) to
> SDSL at 768K (!!!!)
>
> There is ABSOLUTELY no difference in zoning times in Everquest. So don't
> get your hopes up that getting that nifty cable modem, DSL Line (or playing
> on that T1 at work when your boss isn't looking) is gonna erase the annoying
> zone time.
>
> There is one difference though... In the analog world I saw that anything
> over about 5-7 pct packet loss would create lag. At the ping times I'm
> getting now (averages around 125 - occasionally I see two digits pings and
> sometimes close to 200) Even packet loss of close to 20 pct doesn't really
> cause noticeable lag...
>
> The biggest advantage of course - when it has to download a patch - the time
> download time is basically instantaneous.
>
> Slyde
>
>
> ----- Original Message -----

> > >>to Qeynos. Gates back to Freeport. Bard arrives in West

> > >>Yeah, Selo's makes up for all of that.
